entry.title: An insiderâ€™s guide to Oklahoma City
entry.summary:
Intersected by Americaâ€™s legendary Route 66, Oklahoma City exemplifies the bold spirit of the modern American West. In this welcoming city, travellers can visit a working cattle stockyard, shop for authentic Western wear, tour world-class museums or kayak down a wild river under the vast prairie sky. Visitors will find inventive cocktails, stellar Mexican cuisine and exciting tasting menus featuring local produce all across the city.
Start exploring with a self-guided tour of the domed Oklahoma State Capitol. The grand building is known for its impressive collection of art, including a striking bucking bronco sculpture outside, as well as paintings of Indigenous life by the late American artist and politician Enoch Kelly Haney. Nearby, the First Americans Museum, which opened in 2021,â€¦

entry.title: What are 'football pilgrimages' and why are they on the rise?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Before the first whistle blows, you feel it â€” the drums, the tremors, the electricity rising from a crowd that lives and breathes the game. This is football in South America, and itâ€™s exactly what hooked sports writer Christopher Hylland, sending him on marathon ground-hopping adventures across the continent. With â€˜football pilgrimagesâ€™ booming among fans hungry for authenticity, he lays out what makes these journeys irresistible â€” and why, sometimes, a match is worth crossing an ocean for.
Among many fans in the UK and Europe in particular, thereâ€™s a rejection of the commercialised state of â€˜modern footballâ€™, and I think thatâ€™s why ground-hopping trips or â€˜football pilgrimagesâ€™ abroad have become so popular receâ€¦

entry.title: Cow uses tools to scratch self in scientific first
entry.summary:
Veronika, a Swiss brown cow living in Austria. Veronika the cow has learned to scratch herself with deck brushes and other tools. Scientists took note.
Veronika, a cow living in an idyllic mountain village in the Austrian countryside, has spent years perfecting the art of scratching herself with sticks, rakes, and deck brushes. Now that scientists have discovered her, she has the distinction of the first cow known to use tools.Â
She picks up objects with her tongue, grips them tight with her mouth, and directs their ends to where she wants them most. When sheâ€™s wielding a deck brush, she will use the bristled end to scratch her thick-skinned back, but switches to the smooth handle when scratching her soft, sensitive belly.Â
In a new study, published in the journal Currentâ€¦

entry.title: How Gregor Mendelâ€™s pea plant experiments created modern genetics
entry.summary:
Gregor Mendel, Austrian botanist and founder of genetics, poses for a photograph circa 1860. Between 1856-1863, Mendel bred almost 30,000 pea plants in his monastery garden which demonstrated that hereditary characteristics were inherited from the parent plants. Mendelâ€™s monastery garden experiments went largely unnoticed during his life, but their implications would ripple through science decades later.
Hidden away in a rural monastery in current-day Brno, Czech Republic, Gregor Johann Mendel planted the seeds of modern genetics.Â
Known today as the â€œfather of modern genetics,â€ the Austrian peasantâ€™s chosen career as anÂ Augustinian monkÂ had gotten off to a disappointing start: He had been deemed unfit to work as a parish priest due to â€œunconquerable timidity,â€ as his mentor, â€¦

entry.summary: Despite a downward trend in the use of the death penalty globally, 2025 saw an â€˜alarmingâ€™ increase in the number of executions in a small number of retentionist countries, the UN human rights office (OHCHR) warned on Monday.

entry.title: Sudan: Atrocities â€˜repeated town by townâ€™, ICC prosecutor tells UN Security Council
entry.summary: Atrocities in Sudanâ€™s Darfur region are spreading from town to town in an organized campaign of violence that includes mass executions, rape and ethnic targeting, amounting to war crimes and crimes against humanity, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court told the UN Security Council on Monday.

entry.title: Watch Artemis II roll out aboard the heaviest vehicle on Earth
entry.summary:
For the first time since the end of the Apollo program in 1972, humans are returning to the moon. And while they wonâ€™t land on the surface, NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch, and Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen plan to slingshot around the moon on the Artemis II mission this spring. All eyes are on February 6, 2025, which is when the launch window opens.
In preparation for the big day, NASA personnel moved the Artemis II rocket to its launch pad this weekendâ€”and it was no easy feat. It involved a complex choreography with some of the most massive machines on Earth.
Artemis II consists of the Orion crew capsuleâ€”with its launch abort systemâ€”nestled on top of the behemoth SLS rocket. All told, it stands 322 feet tall and weighs roughly 3.5 million pounâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Sydney
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The capital of New South Wales is a city of grand harbours and glorious beaches, with a laidback lifestyle to suit its coastal locale. With just 14 hours to explore the city, it's possible to discover the nearby tropical rainforest, enjoy salmon ceviche while watching the surfers beachside and raise a glass in front of the Harbour Bridge â€” here are the best things to see and do.
Watching the sun come up over the Pacific Ocean isnâ€™t just a pastime in Sydney â€” itâ€™s a ritual. Head first thing to Bronte, a laid-back beachside suburb on the cityâ€™s eastern coast for a windswept dip in its ocean-fed rock pool. Bronte Baths isnâ€™t as famous as Bondi Icebergs, a mile north, but its position on the southern edge of the beacâ€¦

entry.title: UN rights chief bears witness to trauma and resilience in Sudan
entry.summary: Nearly three years of war have plunged Sudan â€œinto an abyss of unimaginable dimensionsâ€ and human rights must be at the centre of efforts to end the fighting and build lasting peace, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Sunday in Nairobi.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tokyo listening barsâ€”what are they and where to find them
entry.summary:
Talking is generally allowed in listening bars, yet it is often seen to disturb the music experience. The phenomenon of listening bars originated in Japan â€” and in frenetic Tokyo they offer a unique way to switch off, wind down and find inner peace.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the Tokyo pleasure district of Shibuya, amid the nightclubs and the love hotels, an electric sign flickers a pink slogan: â€˜Music from the BYGâ€™. I walk through the door and find myself inside a classic rock â€™nâ€™ roll drinking hole. Twentysomethings sit clustered around wooden tables, leather jackets studded with spikes and hair sculpted into rockabilly pompadours. Half-smoked cigarettes billow plumes of smoke from silver ashtrays. Monochrome renderings of Elvis Prâ€¦

entry.title: Gaza humanitarian crisis â€˜far from being over,â€™ UN aid coordination office warns
entry.summary: Three months into the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, the UN and partners have delivered tonnes of assistance items and carried out critical repairs, but this is only a temporary â€œBand-Aidâ€ solution, a veteran aid worker has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Secretary-General on UN at 80: Humanity strongest when we stand as one
entry.summary: Powerful forces are lining up to undermine global cooperation, United Nations Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned at a landmark event in London on Saturday to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the General Assembly, but he urged that â€œhumanity is strongest when we stand as oneâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Will AI kickstart a new age of nuclear power?
entry.summary: The rapidly expanding use of artificial intelligence worldwide is putting electrical grids under huge pressure and many believe that, to meet that need without contributing to the climate crisis, a full-scale expansion of nuclear energy is essential.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Can the cruise industry go carbon-neutral?
entry.summary:
Emissions from cruises in Antarctica have found to be higher than anywhere else in the world. Can the cruise industry hit its carbon-neutral targets? A new generation of ultra-low emission vessels may hold the answer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In November 2021, the Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA) made an ambitious proposal. Its member lines, which together form 95% of the global cruise fleet, announced a collective pledge to pursue net-zero emissions by 2050. Perhaps recognising the scale of the undertaking, Pierfrancesco Vago, then chairman of CLIA Global, was quick to adopt a tone of cautious optimism. â€œWe know there is more to be done,â€ he said. â€œBut the cruise industry has shown both its commitment and its capability tâ€¦

entry.title: 5,000-year-old harpoons are the oldest direct evidence of whaling
entry.summary:
Picture of Krista McGrath analyzing one of the harpoons that early humans living in present-day Brazil may have used to hunt whales, sharks, and seals. Once dismissed as sticks and forgotten in a museum, the 5,000-year-old tools show prehistoric people hunted whales far from the Arctic.
Ancient "sticks" nearly forgotten in a Brazilian museum may actually be 5,000-year-old harpoons used to hunt whales, seals, and sharks, researchers reported last week. If confirmed, the discovery may be the oldest direct evidence of whale hunting yet found, pushing back the timeline for direct evidence of whaling by more than 1,000 years.
The finding, published in Nature Communications, suggests that the marine hunting practice was not limited to just the cold waters of the near-Arctic but â€¦

entry.title: Wellness travel in 2026â€”here's what's trending
entry.summary:
Travellers in 2026 are looking to escape the city for even more elemental experiences. From glowcations to rage retreats, these are the wellness travel trends set to take off in the months ahead.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
If 2025 was the year of longevity retreats and digital detoxing, 2026 is all about returning to the elements. That could mean plunging into glacial waters, swapping spa hotels for cabins in the woods, taking on outdoor endurance challenges or exploring ancient healing practices in the countries where they originate. Here, we take a closer look at what to expect in the coming year.
(The rise of wellness travel, from rewilding to yoga and pilgrimages.)
What began as a quirky experiment in Japan has become oneâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend a day in the footsteps of Edinburgh's literary greats
entry.summary:
The waterfront neighbourhood of Leith is a refreshing hotspot for trendy wine bars and traditional pubs in Edinburgh. Gothic monuments, riverside restaurants and the Royal Mile: here's how to make the most of a short break in this Scottish city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Scotland's capital may be best known for its raucous summertime festival and moody gothic architecture, but even a short break here offers plenty more besides. Pull up a pint in a historic tavern, dine at the acclaimed restaurant where author Irvine Welsh is a regular and climb to the top of Arthur's Seat for shimmering views of the Firth of Forth â€” all over the course of a single day.
Edinburgh is a walkable city, so itâ€™s possible to plot your own literary trailâ€¦

entry.title: Falling vaccination rates in schools
entry.summary: In some counties, vaccination rates increased after the pandemic, which got them pastâ€¦ Tags: school, vaccination, Washington Post

entry.title: Is it raining or snowing? Here's why that's complicated.
entry.summary:
It is easy to tell at a glance whether or not it's snowing, but accurately measuring how much it is snowing presents numerous challenges. Scientists are using lasers, satellites and even sound to determine what is falling from the skyâ€”but the best tool may still be the human eye.
From kids with hopes of sledding to adults wanting to avoid slippery roads, northern winters bring a lot of anticipation of snowfall. But the simple question â€œIs it snowing?â€ is more complicated than it appears.
On a remote mountaintop in Colorado, the Storm Peak Laboratory has a strange winter setup: scientists scurry around, placing more than 30 radar and sampling instruments in different parts of the mountain, on different frequencies, to get at a simple question: what, exactly, is falling from theâ€¦

entry.title: Reading books can help you live longerâ€”here's how
entry.summary:
Reading may be more powerful than you realize. Mounting evidence suggests it can lower stress, protect against cognitive decline, and even extend your life. â€œWhen you get lost in a book, you often enter a trance-like state similar to meditation and that state is deeply protective.â€
Every January, many of us resolve to finally read more. A new book appears on the nightstand, an audiobook gets downloaded, or we dust off an old library card. We keep finding our way back to it because reading feels like a wholesome promise of more calm, curiosity, and escape.Â
But research increasingly suggestsÂ that reading may be more powerful than we realize. In fact, doing so regularly has been linked to lower stress, stronger memory, protection against cognitive decline and dementia, and even â€¦

entry.title: Why do women get more migraines than men?
entry.summary:
One fact that makes a girlâ€™s head hurt: Adult women are three times more likely to get migraines than men. And now, a global 2025 study has found women also spend more time suffering from migraines overall.
Published in The Lancet Neurology in December, the study analyzed headache data from 41,000 male and female patients across 18 countries. While previous headache papers demonstrate women experience migraines more often, researchers wanted to understand if women also suffer longer.
â€œPrevalence in itself doesn't actually provide that much information,â€ says Andreas Kattem HusÃ¸y, one of the lead study authors and a postdoctoral fellow at the Norwegian Center for Headache Research. â€œYou also need to know how the disease affects individuals.â€
(What's behind the rise of migrainâ€¦

entry.title: Inside NASAâ€™s plan to defeat moon dust
entry.summary:
Within NASAâ€™s sprawling Johnson Space Center in Houston are a series of workshops affectionately known as the dirty labs. Inside, through a maze of corridors, cavernous hangars, and claustrophobic rooms, there is dust everywhere: in petri dishes, tubes, boxes, vats, atriums, and crates. In one windowless room filled with storage containers, a large translucent box is pried open, revealing a gray-black miniature desert of remarkably fine powder, and Iâ€™m invited to plunge my ungloved hand into it.
It feels like talcum powder but way more adhesive and curiously dense. After swimming through it for a few seconds, I withdraw my hand and find that itâ€™s completely covered. Shaking my hand, and brushing it, doesnâ€™t seem to dislodge any of the powder. The feeling is distinctly alien. And tâ€¦

entry.title: These small towns in western North Carolina are big on charm
entry.summary:
These North Carolina small towns are rebuilding after Hurricane Helene devastated the area in 2024. From Banner Elk to Hot Springs, these towns in the western part of the state have worked hard to rebuild after Hurricane Heleneâ€”and theyâ€™re ready to welcome back visitors.
The great thing about small towns is that they all have their own unique personalitiesâ€”you never quite know what youâ€™re going to experience until you slow down enough to explore.
Western North Carolina is a classic example. Everywhere you stop, thereâ€™s something worth checking out. However, 2024's Hurricane Helene threatened to destroy some of these small towns. Rather than give up, North Carolina came together. Here, there are stories of how hard it was and how the communities worked together to ensure the toâ€¦

entry.title: Gestational diabetes is rising fast. Hereâ€™s what doctors say can help lower the risk.
entry.summary:
Low-impact movement, including swimming, may play a larger role in pregnancy health than once thought. Research suggests that consistent, low-risk activity can help regulate blood sugar by improving insulin sensitivity. Rates jumped 36 percent in less than a decade.
For decades, gestational diabetes has been treated as a routineâ€”if unwelcomeâ€”part of pregnancy. But new research suggests itâ€™s becoming far more common than doctors expected.
According to a new study analyzing over 12 million births, cases of gestational diabetes have increased 36 percent over the past nine years and have been steadily rising for the past 15.
â€œWe were expecting some increase in gestational diabetes, given the broader trends of higher rates of obesity that are important risk factors for the devâ€¦

entry.summary: Myanmar on Friday rejected allegations of genocide against the Rohingya minority, telling the International Court of Justice (ICJ) that the Gambiaâ€™s case rests on â€œunsubstantiated allegations,â€ as public hearings continued in a landmark case on the application of the Genocide Convention.

entry.title: This little-known type of fat may actually protect your heart
entry.summary:
A colored scanning electron micrograph shows clusters of fat-storing cells, or adipocytes. While white fat primarily stores energy, brown fat burns it to generate heatâ€”and beige fat, which sits within white fat, can switch between the two roles. Researchers are now uncovering how these differences may influence blood pressure and heart health. A new mouse study suggests that "beige" fat surrounding blood vessels can send calming signals to the arteriesâ€”revealing an unexpected biological link between fat tissue and heart health.
Too much fat in the body is associated with a host of negative effects, including high blood pressureâ€”or hypertensionâ€”a condition that plagues nearly 50 percent of U.S. adults. Itâ€™s easy to assume that less fat is always a good thing. But the effects of fat â€¦

entry.title: Steroid use is more widespread than most people believe
entry.summary:
As a kid, Daniel Coffeen wasnâ€™t very athletic. By his own description, he was a tweener in the 2000s, stuck between two extremes: too small to push opponents aroundÂ but too slow to utilize his slim frame. After he finished high school in New Mexico, Coffeen went to college where he enrolled in the ROTC program. After graduation, he joined the Army and later completedÂ Ranger School, a rigorous voluntary training course intended to prepare soldiers for missions under tremendous stress. As he trained with specialized units, Coffeen observed performance-enhancing drug (PED) use for the first time. He says he saw soldiers using PEDsâ€”from over-the-counter pills that contained anabolic steroids to anabolic steroids themselves. But he wasnâ€™t ready to take the plunge himself.
PED use wasnâ€™t enâ€¦

entry.title: Utah's Deer Valley beckons skiers this seasonâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
Deer Valley Resort is an ever-popular destination for skiiers of all levels. Guides are at the ready for those, who want to improve on their skills. This season, Deer Valley sees the biggest expansion of any US ski resort in more than 50 years, shining a spotlight on Utahâ€™s old mining backcountry.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œI sent 900 potential names for the new runs,â€ says Michael Oâ€™Malley, my ski guide. His kind, weathered face suddenly takes on a solemn look. The retired executiveâ€™s self-nominated task took weeks of research. â€œI waded through reels and reels of old microfilm and maps in the basement of Park City Museum looking for the names of mining claims for inspiration, and Iâ€™m delighted some suggestions made the cut, especially â€¦

entry.title: The uncertain future of the world's most expensive spice
entry.summary:
Shubli Bashir, a PhD student studying agriculture at Sher e Kashmir University, harvests saffron crocuses on her family's plot in Pampore. Facing pests, climate change, deforestation, the region's saffron harvest has been steadily declining. After facing one of its worst harvests on record, the Kashmir Valleyâ€™s farmers worry about the future of their prized saffron.
Pampore, KashmirNoorÂ MohdÂ Bhat is aÂ second-generationÂ farmer who hasÂ workedÂ the Kashmir Valleyâ€™s saffron fields since the summer of 1947. Cloistered in his familyâ€™s shop on the side of the highway near the town of Pampore, the octogenarian sat at his desk sorting a giant pile of the spice.Â
For just three days out of the year, the thousands of purple crocus flowers that grow here bloom in the fall, exposing the daâ€¦

entry.title: 6 sun-soaked island archipelagos to visit for a winter getaway
entry.summary:
Travelers looking to escape the cold weather should consider a warm-weather getaway to the Caribbean, specifically Antigua and Barbuda. These destinations are ideal for snorkeling, hiking, or enjoying a good book on a palm-lined beach.
When the cold months begin to take a toll, a change of scenery might be the perfect antidote, especially if it involves clear blue waters and warm trade winds. Studies show that spending timeÂ near the coastÂ can improve our overall well-being, and the calming effect often feels even stronger on islands. Life moves a little slower there, making it easier to relax, reconnect with nature, and truly unwind.
Trading gray-sky mornings for palm-lined beaches offers an instant boost, whether youâ€™re snorkeling colorful reefs, hiking rainforest trails, or â€¦

entry.title: A marine scientist explains why she eats seafoodâ€”even octopus
entry.summary:
The supply chain for seafood is large, complex, and often murky, making it difficult for consumers to ethically and sustainably eat seafood. Conservationist Christina Hicks explains the tension between protecting marine life and depending on it for food, and how our seafood choices ripple across the world.
Seafood is delicious. But for those of us who love the ocean, consuming the species that come from it may spark a twinge of guilt.Â
How do you reconcile eating the very creatures you adore?
Christina Hicks, a marine conservationist and professor of environmental social science at Lancaster University, has spent her career studying how to balance ocean conservation withÂ fishing. Her research has taken her from coral reefs to coastal markets, tracing how the global seafooâ€¦

entry.title: Revealing the hidden kingdom of seahorses
entry.summary: Heather Mason wasÂ used to her quarry being much more elusive. Seahorses are often only a few inches long, can change colors like a chameleon, and rarely gather in groups. Their ability to disappear into their habitatsâ€”tropical seagrasses, mangroves, and reefsâ€”helps keep the slow-swimming, largely defenseless fish from becoming an easy meal. That makes devoting a career to studying them, as Mason, a marine ecologist at the University of Tampa, has done for decades, an exercise in patience. But when she first snorkeled the pristine waters of Sweetings Pond on the Bahamian island of Eleuthera, she found herself in a seahorse-studded heaven. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2602-Seahorse-Bahamas-Map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Over her first weekend in the pondâ€™s câ€¦

entry.title: How scientists are using virtual reality to treat chronic pain
entry.summary:
Virtual reality isnâ€™t just for games. Researchers are studying how immersive digital environments may help people manage chronic pain. Once used mainly for distraction, VR is now being studied as a way to retrain the brainâ€™s pain pathwaysâ€”especially for people with chronic and hard-to-treat conditions.
It was a late afternoon in September when Leona Bell was heading home from her job as a senior systems engineer for a company that designs defibrillators and resuscitation equipment in Seattle. The company had just moved offices, and the new workstations had built-in laptop chargers. When she went to grab her computer, she yelped in pain. â€œI got shocked,â€ she says. â€œIt changed my life.â€
When Bell woke the next morning, her right hand, injured by the electrical shock, was swollenâ€¦

entry.title: Cheetah mummies provide rare genome from a lost population
entry.summary:
One of seven mummified cheetahs found in caves in Saudi Arabia. Researchers sequenced the cheetahs' genomes and found they were similar to two cheetah subspecies that are still alive today. Preserved by dry, cool air and darkness, the cheetah mummies are offering scientists DNA insights into a lost population and ideas for bringing it back.
In 2022, researchers with Saudi Arabiaâ€™s National Center for Wildlife set out to explore a vast cave network in search of bats, bugs, and other biodiversity. But hidden within the remote and nearly unreachable cavesâ€”one of which could only be entered by descending into a 50-foot-deep sinkholeâ€”they uncovered something jaw-dropping: seven mummified cheetahs, with fangs poking out from their leathery lips.
Finding the cheetah remains "was a suâ€¦

entry.title: Game-changing international marine protection treaty comes into force
entry.summary: Almost two decades in the making, an international agreement to protect marine life in international waters and the seabed is due to come into force on Saturday, marking a major step forward in efforts to ensure the health of ocean ecosystems for decades to come.

entry.title: In Gaza, 800,000 people now live in dangerous locations prone to flooding
entry.summary: Fighting the harsh winter storms in Gaza, Amina stays awake at night, hitting the canvas of the tent above her head to prevent it from collapsing under the pooled water.

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors due to meet in emergency session on Iran
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is scheduled to meet at 3 PM in New York on Thursday to discuss the situation in Iran, where hundreds of people reportedly have been killed in recent anti-government protests.

entry.title: WFP warns Sudan food aid could run out in March
entry.summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) said on Thursday that it is struggling to keep emergency operations running in Sudan, where more than 1,000 days of war have pushed families to the brink.

entry.title: Woolly rhino genome recovered from frozen wolf's stomach
entry.summary:
The woolly rhinoceros is an extinct species of rhinoceros that was common throughout Europe and northern Asia during the Pleistocene epoch. Scientists recently sequenced the genome of a woolly rhino from the tissue found inside a frozen 14,400-year-old wolf. The work marks the first time an Ice Age animalâ€™s complete genome has been recovered from tissue preserved inside another ancient animal.
In 2011, mammoth ivory hunters in northeastern Siberia discovered a mummified wolf puppy that had lain frozen for 14,400 years. An autopsy of the permafrost-preserved pup revealed another surprise: its gut contained chunks of grayish meat covered with strands of golden hair.
â€œThe tissue was so intact, it looked like the wolf had just swallowed it before it died,â€ says Camilo ChacÃ³n-Duqueâ€¦

entry.title: How the Romans became the greatest builders in the ancient world
entry.summary:
The Roman world was bound to the capital by the invisible web of law and custom, and a tangible network of roads, aqueducts, sewers, and ports. This spectacle of infrastructure, whose ruins still provoke awe, proclaimed Romeâ€™s preeminence across Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa.
Engineering was one of Romeâ€™s most lasting legacies. Adopting technologies already invented by the Greeks, Etruscans, Egyptians, and Babylonians, the Romans refined them with their own utilitarian spirit.
Utility, or utilitas, was central to Roman thinking. Vitruvius, the first-century B.C. Roman engineer, architect, and theorist, reflected on his admiration for the mathematicians and engineers on whom Roman greatness was built: â€œmen whose researches are an everlasting possession, not only for thâ€¦

entry.title: Ride the world's steepest cable-car to this remote Swiss village
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Only in Switzerland can you speed down a slope racing against a train. Skiing Jungfrauâ€™s piste 36 brings me alongside the distinctive red carriages of a Jungfrau Railway train, its locomotive whirring as I sweep down the piste, carving turns to steady my velocity just as the cogs on the train control its speed on the steep descent. And at the bottom, in Wengen, thereâ€™s time to get myself a coffee and strudel before taking the train back up, observing other peopleâ€™s technique â€” or lack of it.
If youâ€™re itching for action, that ride back up, however congenial, can feel a bit slow. But from this winter, the long-awaited completion of the vertigo-inducing Schilthornbahn 20XX cable-car offers a fast-track to explore Juâ€¦

entry.title: HPV is more commonâ€”and misunderstoodâ€”than you think
entry.summary:
Colorized transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of human papillomavirus (HPV) particles. This common virus can infect various parts of the body, with some instances causing cervical, vulvar, and vaginal cancers. This sexually transmitted infection is almost entirely preventable. Here's what experts say you really need to know to protect yourself.
NearlyÂ every AmericanÂ willÂ contract theÂ human papillomavirus (HPV) in their lifetime, and over 40 million Americans currently have HPV. Globally,Â hundreds of thousandsÂ of cancer cases annually are attributed to the virus.Â With over 200 strains, â€œHPV infection is just so common and so ubiquitous,â€ saysÂ June Hou, a gynecologic oncologist at Columbia University Irving Medical Center.Â
Hereâ€™s what HPV is, how it spreads, and what the sciâ€¦

entry.title: 9 spectacular state parks to visit this winter
entry.summary:
Travelers looking for less crowded alternatives to U.S. National Parks should consider visiting state parks such as Utahâ€™s 5,362-acre Dead Horse Point State Park, which features an overlook of the Colorado River and Canyonlands National Park. From ice fishing to toboggan racing to skiing in a ghost town, winter adventures hit differently in these less-crowded alternatives to national parks.
Winter strips landscapes down to their essentialsâ€”quiet, contour, lightâ€”and in that stillness, Americaâ€™s State Parks reveal a different kind of drama. Unlike spring, summer, and autumn, when crowds clamor along boardwalks and struggle to see wildlife and fall foliage amid so many people, cold-weather months usually attract fewer visitors.
However, as wonderful as it is to explore a park in â€¦

entry.title: What is black ice? The science behind the winter threat
entry.summary: A woman tries to regain balance in icy conditions on her way to work to avoid falling on black ice. An estimated 1 million people are injured from slipping on ice and snow across the U.S. each year, leading to serious issues like broken bones and head injuries, with around 17,000 of these falls proving fatal, according to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Nearly invisible and deceptively thin, this ice is one of winterâ€™s deadliest hazards. Hereâ€™s how it forms and why it causes thousands of accidents each year. When the weather is calling forÂ winter storms, drivers know to prepare for roads with slippery sleet andÂ snow. But there is an invisible hazard that canâ€¦

entry.title: The best night-sky apps, according to the experts
entry.summary:
These apps and recommendations from experts will help you learn about what you're seeing when you gaze up at the night sky. Hoping for a glimpse of the Milky Way? These user-friendly apps help stargazers learn more about objects in the sky, check visibility for prime Milky Way viewing, or even locate the International Space Station.
Where was I when a magenta aurora borealis could be seen as far south as Florida? Indoors and not paying enough attention. Thankfully, there are multiple apps for that.
â€œMany visitors come to Dark Sky Parks for a chance to see the Milky Way, since 80 percent of Americans can't see it from their hometown,â€ says Jackie Rabb, a Mesa Verde National Park ranger and night sky lead at this certified International Dark Sky Park. Apps can help you â€œfigure oâ€¦

entry.title: The UN is â€˜worth fighting forâ€™: General Assembly President
entry.summary: With the multilateral system under pressure and under attack, Member States must fight for the United Nations, the President of the General Assembly said on Wednesday, laying out her priorities for its resumed 80th session.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemenâ€™s fragile calm unravels as hunger and aid restrictions deepen crisis
entry.summary: A fragile political calm in Yemen is fraying, with renewed instability and aid restrictions deepening hunger, illness and displacement for millions of civilians, senior UN officials warned the Security Council on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: East Jerusalem: Forced shutdown of UN clinic signals escalating disregard for international law
entry.summary: The temporary closure of a UN-run health centre in East Jerusalem is the latest phase in â€œa pattern of deliberate disregardâ€ for international law, the head of the UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA, said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 11-year streak of record global warming continues, UN weather agency warns
entry.summary: The past 11 years have been the warmest in the modern era, while oceans continue to heat up, too, says the UN weather agency.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global employment stable but decent jobs in short supply
entry.summary: Global unemployment remains stable, but progress toward decent work has stalled, according to a new report from the International Labour Organization (ILO), which warns that young people continue to struggle in a job market which risks being further undermined by AI and trade policy uncertainty.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fatherâ€™s letters
entry.summary: Spinning imaginative tales, a father wrapped his daughter in a protective layer of love all the way from an island gulag - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Meet the GalapagueÃ±os who are trying to save paradise
entry.summary:
The GalÃ¡pagos are home to both incredible wildlife, such as great blue herons, and a band of locals, who protect them. The GalÃ¡pagos may be famed for its giant tortoises and blue-footed boobies, but its people are just as extraordinary. From naturalists and park guards to farmers and biologists, meet the GalÃ¡pagueÃ±os safeguarding this fragile paradise for future generations.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Why did the giant tortoise cross the road? To hold up a busload of tourists, it seems. This one is standing in the middle of the barely gravelled track, casting a slow, menacing side-eye that suggests we must wait as long as it takes. I loop my camera around my neck and rush to the front of the bus â€” though this isnâ€™t exactly a blink-and-yoâ€¦

entry.title: Bolted inside a steel sphere deep underwater, these explorers made history
entry.summary:
This story originally published in the June 1931 issue ofÂ National GeographicÂ magazine.Â See more digitized stories from our archives here.
Several years ago I climbed overboard into the clear waters of Haiti, and after a copper helmet had been lowered over my head and shoulders I slid slowly down a rope two, four, eight, ten fathoms and finally at sixty-three feet my canvas shoes settled into the soft ooze near a coral reef. I made my way to a steep precipice, balanced on the brink, and looked down, down into the green depths where illumination like moonlight showed waving sea-fans and milling fish far beyond the length of my hose.
It would have been exceedingly unwise to go much farther, for the steady force of the weight of water at ten fathoms had already increased the pressuâ€¦

entry.title: See a ghost 'fairyland' forest reemerge in Florida
entry.summary:
A snorkeler explores the fish-filled depths of Tobacco Patch Spring, one of at least 20 springs that were lost when the Rodman Reservoir was created by damming Florida's Ocklawaha River. Tobacco Patch and the other springs are normally submerged beneath the dark waters of the reservoir, but a few of them become visible during periodic drawdowns. Sixty years ago, these freshwater springs and forests were drowned by a 9,500-acre reservoir. Could the ecosystem finally be restored?
On New Yearâ€™s morning, Captain Erika Ritter wakes before dawn in the cabin on Floridaâ€™s Ocklawaha River her grandfather built in 1937 out of pine logs and cypress timber from the nearby swamp. She operates river tours aboard her pontoon boat, â€œThe Anhinga Spirit,â€ and has to prepare for back-to-back chartersâ€¦
